image.altText: Piles of dead garfish in fridge at grocery store

props.synopsis: The SA government is placing temporary restrictions on fishing in the Gulf St Vincent and Spencer Gulf as results from fish stock monitoring show declining numbers of some species.

title.children: Government announces fishing restrictions amid ongoing algal bloom

image.altText: The infamous bank building in the township of Snowtown.

props.synopsis: It comes a day after the ABC revealed that the South Australian attorney-general had called for a review of the decision to release James Vlassakis on parole.

title.children: Parole Board 'erred' in Snowtown killer's parole decision, SA attorney-general says

image.altText: A close-up of fresh fish for sale at a market.

props.synopsis: There are microplastics in almost everything, so why does seafood get such a bad reputation? Scientists say it is down to disproportionate research and media attention.

title.children: Microplastics 'misconception' hurting seafood sector, scientists say

image.altText: A man in a wheelchair sits with crossed arms outside a blue office building with three steps

props.synopsis: A viral video showing a lack of accessibility into the offices of the federal minister for disability has highlighted broader issues for access into public buildings, an advocate says.

title.children: Advocate says federal disability minister's office is inaccessible

image.altText: A man carrying documents outside a court.

props.synopsis: Member for MacKillop Nick McBride is facing another three counts of assault dating back to January and September of 2024.

title.children: South Australian MP facing further charges of assault

image.altText: composite image of sick greyhound

props.synopsis: Staff at Greyhound Racing SA accuse the organisation of suppressing complaints about its preferred vet, according to documents and graphic photos tabled in state parliament.

title.children: Vet sent greyhounds home with 'open wounds', SA parliament told

image.altText: Talia Scriven sits amongst brown reeds wearing large rattan earrings and a beige jacket. She has brown hair.

props.synopsis: A first-of-its-kind South Australian study finds access to compensation after a road accident is not good enough for First Nations people.

title.children: Road accident compensation not culturally safe, study says

image.altText: a plane flies in the sky

props.synopsis: Creditors owed millions of dollars remain in the dark despite a new owner being found for the embattled airline.

title.children: Rex creditors fear they will be left millions out of pocket with US sale

image.altText: People at ceremony for the repatriation of Aboriginal remains.

props.synopsis: An emotional ceremony for the repatriation of Aboriginal remains that had been held by institutions, including the South Australian Museum, has been held in Adelaide's north at a site that is now a resting place for hundreds of Kaurna ancestors.

title.children: Repatriation brings 'tears of joy' as remains re-buried after decades

image.altText: Tess Craven of the Kangaroos attempts to take a mark.

props.synopsis: One of the biggest challenges the AFLW faces is end-of-year "footy fatigue", according to diehard fans and industry insiders.

title.children: 'Footy fatigue' leaves AFLW struggling for attention after men's season

image.altText: Premier Peter Malinauskas speaks with a police officer next to a police motorbike

props.synopsis: People found guilty of harassing or stalking a police officer or members of their family could face up to 10 years in prison under new laws proposed by the state government.

title.children: Premier proposes laws to protect police and families from harassment

image.altText: The casing of a missile on a salt lake bed.

props.synopsis: Traditional owners win a decision against a multinational weapons manufacturer after finding one of the company's missiles at a heritage site in the remote South Australian outback.

title.children: Maker of missile found in outback 'directly linked' to human rights harm

image.altText: A man in a suit with an apprehensive face arrives at a court house

props.synopsis: Former South Australian MP Troy Bell will spend at least two-and-half years in jail for stealing more than $430,000 in public money meant for not-for-profit education organisations.

title.children: Former SA MP Troy Bell jailed for fraud offending

image.altText: A man covered in mud carrying a sack on his back while smoking a cigarette.

props.synopsis: Unlike the name suggests, rare earths are not very rare at all. The critical minerals are found in abundance in many countries, but being big on reserves may not mean big business.

title.children: Where in the world are all the rare earths?

image.altText: A man stands in a suit speaking.

props.synopsis: A pause on puberty blockers was issued in January, which is being challenged in court. David Crisafulli says the decision was made to "keep kids safe".

title.children: Queensland premier backs puberty blocker pause with legal challenge underway

image.altText: A close up shot of a tanned man, gray hair, black-framed glasses, plaid pattern button up shirt.

props.synopsis: Central Land Council chief executive Lesley Turner — who is suing Jacinta Nampijinpa Price for defamation — testifies in Federal Court, and denies being "embarrassed" by the senator pointing out alleged "failures" of the council.

title.children: Land council boss testifies against Senator Nampijinpa Price in defamation trial

image.altText: A composite image of three men

props.synopsis: The White House makes a sharp move to pressure Moscow to secure peace in Ukraine just one day after a summit between US President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin falls apart.

title.children: US hits  Russia's biggest oil firms with sanctions over Ukraine

image.altText: A hand holding a phone with the BOM website

props.synopsis: As wild weather wreaked havoc across the country, the Bureau of Meteorology launched a new website.

title.children: 'Not happy BOM': Agency's new website causes a storm

image.altText: A bird with green grass stems on its face on a windy day

props.synopsis: The 40 shortlisted images pair talented nature photography with humour that often relies on clicking the shutter at just the right moment.

title.children: In need of a laugh? Check out the finalists of the Comedy Wildlife Photo Awards

image.altText: Donald Trump has his eyes closed as Marco Rubio speaks and Pete Hegseth rests his hands on his kneee

props.synopsis: The Trump administration has expanded its target area in its 'narco-trafficking' offensive, conducting two military strikes in the Pacific and bringing the death toll from its attacks to at least 37.

title.children: US expands target area in new 'war on drugs', attacking boats in Pacific

image.altText: A smiling man in a Santa hat.

props.synopsis: An inquest finds a Sydney fisherman likely drowned after being pulled overboard by a large Mako shark during a game fishing competition near Newcastle.

title.children: Coroner finds shark dragged fisherman entwined in line overboard

image.altText: A group of Aboriginal mourners walking through a coles supermarket, while holding branches.

props.synopsis: Supermarket giant Coles is among the parties expected to take part in a coronial inquest into the death in custody of a young Aboriginal man inside its Alice Springs shop earlier this year.

title.children: Coles to appear at death in custody inquest, as family calls for answers

image.altText: Phil Gore smiles above a caption which reads "PHIL GORE WINNER - 114 LAPS"

props.synopsis: Ultra-athlete Phil Gore is Australia's newest world champion after five days of near-continuous running in Bell Buckle, Tennessee.

title.children: 'Oh, you stink': New ultra world champion Phil Gore craves shower and sleep

image.altText: A composite image of Mark Haines with railway tracks.

props.synopsis: Some key questions about the death of Indigenous teenager Mark Haines are still unanswered after a coronial inquest spanning five weeks.

title.children: After five weeks of evidence, this is what we know about the Mark Haines mystery

image.altText: A person pouring coffee and milk into a white coffee cup to make latte art.

props.synopsis: The Australian coffee industry is growing as new varieties become available and local demand increases.

title.children: More Australian-grown coffee on the horizon amid local bean boom

image.altText: A woman with glasses speaking to the media.

props.synopsis: The NT attorney-general's department has taken the extraordinary step of releasing private emails between a top judge and bureaucrats, to try and address allegations of interference.

title.children: NT attorney-general's department releases private emails with top judge

image.altText: Justin Wolfers Boyer lecture 2025 keynote speaker

props.synopsis: The world changes, yet Australia keeps being great. Our institutions permit us to be nimble, and we adapt.

title.children: Australia's institutions are rare, valuable and worth defending

image.altText: A woman vacuuming a couch

props.synopsis: Hayfever symptoms can be debilitating. Experts give their tips and tricks on helping reduce allergens in the home.

title.children: Simple steps to take at home to prevent hay fever and allergy flare-ups

image.altText: A dark-haired man in a dark suit holds his hand to his chin.

props.synopsis: The International Chess Federation says it will examine Vladimir Kramnik's public attacks on Daniel Naroditsky, the American grandmaster who died at the age of 29 this week.

title.children: Ex-chess world champ facing probe over attacks on late grandmaster

image.altText: A basket lift outside the Louvre museum.

props.synopsis: The Louvre chief says she repeatedly raised concerns about CCTV coverage at the museum, only for her fears to come "horribly true".

title.children: Louvre chief blames CCTV gaps for $157m jewellery heist

image.altText: 4WD behind a police vehicle with flashing light.

props.synopsis: A video of an erratically driven vehicle chasing a police car in Kununurra has been posted on social media.

title.children: Pursuit aborted after juveniles allegedly chase police in stolen cars

image.altText: Four ambulances parked at a hospital.

props.synopsis: A paramedic has been sentenced for stealing vials of an opioid used for pain relief, refilling them with saline and returning them into circulation in WA ambulances.

title.children: Ambulance station manager steals fentanyl, refills vials with saline

image.altText: Trees down.

props.synopsis: Howling winds overnight will lead to extensive clean-up work today in NSW's south-east and parts of Victoria, with October heat records also broken in Western Sydney.

title.children: Parts of NSW and Victoria 'absolutely battered' by howling winds

image.altText: A crowd of people surround a truck, some are climbing on the truck.

props.synopsis: The International Court of Justice rules Israel must allow aid groups access to Gaza and that the nation's attempts to stop a UN agency delivering aid to Palestinians are illegal.

title.children: ICJ rules Israel must allow aid groups unimpeded access to Gaza

image.altText: Jockey Zac Purton lifts his arm into the air in celebration.

props.synopsis: Just days after winning the world's richest horse race, Australian jockey Zac Purton defends himself over what one UK racing identity describes as the worst ride she has seen.

title.children: Everest-winning jockey defends 'worst ever' ride
